docs.title: Welcome to zbitx-wiki
docs.text: This is a starter MkDocs site with the Material theme.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
Use this template as a base to build your own zBITX documentation site.

© 2025 N5QC. Content licensed under CC BY 4.0.

docs.title: About zBITX
docs.text:
zBITX is an open-source, modular software and hardware platform based on the BITX series of radios. It is designed for amateur radio operators and developers who want to build, modify, and experiment with modern digital and analog radio systems.

This wiki provides documentation for setup, configuration, modifications, and contributions to the zBITX project. Whether you?re building your first radio or extending the software, we welcome your participation!

  • Website: https://n5qc.github.io/zbitx-wiki
  • GitHub Repository: https://github.com/n5qc/zbitx-wiki

docs.title: Backlog
docs.text:
This backlog tracks features, documentation, and polish ideas for the zbitz wiki.

Items may move between sections as work progresses.

docs.title: Sprint Candidates
docs.text:
These are the prioritized tasks likely to be tackled in upcoming sprints.

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text: This changelog documents notable updates to the zBITX Wiki.

• ? Initial working deployment to GitHub Pages at zbitx-wiki
  • ? Added basic content pages: About, Changelog, Contributing, FAQ, Hardware, Software
  • ? Implemented flat file structure with MkDocs

• ?? Debugged deployment errors due to GitHub case sensitivity
  • ? Initial test builds and manual staging on Raspberry Pi

docs.title: OLD Changelog
docs.text: All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

docs.title: [Unreleased]
docs.text:
• Initial clean flat-file structure established.
  • Basic pages added: Home, Hardware, Software, FAQ, Backlog, Contributing.
  • MkDocs project hosted on Raspberry Pi, tested and served locally.

• Project initialized and working on Raspberry Pi.
  • Created index.md, hardware.md, software.md, and other core pages.

docs.title: Contributing to zBITX Wiki
docs.text: We welcome contributions of all types?corrections, documentation, features, or questions.

docs.title: How to Contribute
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository: n5qc/zbitx-wiki
  2. Create a new branch: git checkout -b my-contribution
  3. Make changes and commit: git commit -m "Describe your change"
  4. Push and open a Pull Request

docs.title: Contribution Guidelines
docs.text:
• Keep language clear and beginner-friendly
  • Break large pages into subtopics when possible
  • Include screenshots, diagrams, or photos if helpful

docs.title: Questions?
docs.text: Open a GitHub Issue or post on the BITX20 group at Groups.io email BITX20@groups.io.

docs.title: Q: What is zBITX?
docs.text: A: zBITX is a modular, open-source platform based on the BITX series transceivers. It includes software and hardware components for amateur radio experimentation.

docs.title: Q: Where is the source code?
docs.text: A: The main source for documentation is this GitHub repository.

docs.title: Q: How do I flash firmware or update the software?
docs.text: A: See the Software page for setup, configuration, and updating instructions.

docs.title: Q: How can I contribute?
docs.text: A: See the Contributing guide for steps on submitting documentation or code changes.

docs.title: Q: Why did I do this?
docs.text: A: I decided that I was going to research the zBITX while I was waiting for my order to deliver. I started making notes and compiling reading material, it dawned on me that it MIGHT be useful to share this info

docs.title: Q: Why did I select a GitHub hosted Wiki?
docs.text: A: I decided that publishing a Wiki via GitHub would be a good learning experience I chose to do the key work locally on a Raspberry Pi for that experience and practice.

docs.title: Q: Is this the best way to do it?
docs.text: A: Not necessarily. In fact probably only based on my personal learning goals.

docs.title: Q: Is this a learning experience for me?
docs.text: A: Yes, that's the goal.

docs.title: Q: Am I willing to share my learning experiences?
docs.text: A: Yes, that's why I'm publishing.

docs.title: Q: Am I trying to compete with Groups dot IO?
docs.text: A: No with the Creative Commons license that I put on this it will already be able to be moved to places including Groups dot io with attribution and as I get further down the road,

docs.title: Q: Is this intended to be a LONG TERM project?
docs.text: A: No, both this documentation and also collaborative development are just getting up to speed and changes are to be expected. Unless this becomes THE definitive core documentation project (not my prediction) I will probably stop maintaining this site and try to transition it to some place that has more longevity. An example of this is Toshen's work on digital voice where he did a lot of good work that is still recognized as THE good overview. However, Toshen has stopped maintaining the work, but has left the PDFs out there for people to read.

docs.title: Hardware Overview
docs.text: This section provides information on zBITX hardware components, schematics, and modifications.

docs.title: Board Layouts
docs.text: Diagrams and labeled images will be added here soon. Check back!

  • USB-C power input upgrade

docs.text:

You are free to:

  • Share - copy and redistribute the material in any medium or format.
  • Adapt - remix, transform, and build upon the material for any purpose, even commercially.

Under the following terms:

  • Attribution - You must give appropriate credit, provide a link to the license, and indicate if changes were made. You may do so in any reasonable manner, but not in any way that suggests the licensor endorses you or your use.

For more information, visit https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/

docs.title: Software Overview
docs.text: This page includes setup instructions, firmware references, and customization tips.

docs.title: Basic Setup
docs.text:
• Install Arduino IDE or PlatformIO
  • Clone the zBITX firmware repository
  • Flash via USB or serial

docs.title: Customization Options
docs.text:
• Configure startup frequency
  • Customize display behavior
  • Enable/disable features like CW keyer or CAT control

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: If the device fails to boot after flashing, hold the reset button and retry upload.

docs.title: Working cp
docs.text:
~~All copied to Travelling CP for laptop editing. 5/31/25~~

Do Backlog grooming.

Get the thoughts together, include literature search and. Pulling in diverse notes. Build the out via notebook LM. Start populating. 

Change Log 
Contributing
FAQ
Hardware
Software
Backlog

Backlog

Software Do a search Mention the A Faron GitHub site, which is the current dev site Mention Forks. Find whatever ones makes sense to list. Include the one with pretty good documentation and build it out and go through. Include the one with shut down Any others that make sense to include

Hardware Pictures and schematics Talk about the general architecture Pi Zero Pico.

History add in some things about overheating and etc.

FAQ. Start building a list there

Contributing change and n5qc e-mail address to the groups dot IO.

Change log.

And once this is done, go ahead and do a literature search and start compiling note. My workflow will go through notebook LM build

Notes to Self CHEAT SHEET and build in the backup schedule, backup plan and anything else that seems to make sense.

And I think that's it for now.

Then pay homage to groups that I owe and uh get all this done and get a good back up and go live.

I think that's about enough for this session, but I'm sure there's more to come.

================================================================================

2025 05 31 Additional Thoughts

Some background about me.

Why did I do this? I decided that I was going to research the Z bit X and started making notes. Looked like it would be useful to share them, so I decided to put them in the wiki. Looking forward to what things I might want to do, I decided that publishing a site via GitHub would be a good learning experience, so I chose to do that on the Raspberry Pi.

Is this the best way to do it? Not necessarily.

Is this a learning experience for me? Yes, that's the goal.

Am I willing to share my learning experiences? Yes, that's why I'm publishing.

Am I trying to compete with Groups dot IO? No with the Creative Commons license that I put on this it will already be able to be moved on to places including Groups dot io with attribution and as I get further down the road, I will probably stop maintaining this site and try to transition it to some place that has more longevity. An example. For model is Toshen's work on digital voice where he did a lot of good work that is still recognized as THE good overview and he has stopped maintaining it but has left the PDF out there for people to read. Probably PDF's that can't be edited and aren't the best bet, but trying to get things over to a site is anyway just some rambling thoughts that need to get put into the FAQ's and etcetera, etcetera.

==============================================

From One Note

docs.title: Currently in collecting point for travelling and editing
Backup and Restore: zbitx-wiki Development Environment
docs.text: This guide describes how to create and restore a backup of the full development environment for the zBITX-Wiki, including all content, configuration, and Git history.

docs.title: Whats Included:
docs.text:
• Project files (Markdown, config, assets, etc.)
  • .git directory with full Git history and local branches
  • Python virtual environment (optional)
  • Local-only notes and untracked files

docs.title: When to Back Up:
docs.text:
• After major changes or successful GitHub Pages deployments
  • Before system upgrades or Raspberry Pi changes
  • Periodically, as insurance against SD card failure

docs.title: Step-by-Step Daily Working Snapshot Backup (from home directory)
docs.text:
Move to your home directory (or parent of zBITX-Wiki)

cd \~

docs.title: Create a compressed archive with today's date
docs.text: ** tar -czf zbitx-wiki-full-backup-$(date +%Y%m%d).tar.gz zbitx-wiki/ **

docs.title: Keep rolling copies in Large Files on N5QC One Drive / HP Desktop
docs.text:
3 -- 2 -- 1 Analyisis

  • 3 Copies

  • Backup on Raspberry Pi Home

  • Copy on HP Laptop 🡪 MyBook External

  • Copy on OneDrive Cloud

  • 2 Different Media

  • Raspberry Pi uSD Card

  • MyBook External (Spinning Magnetic Disk)

  • OneDrive Cloud -- Who knows the media, redundant cloud data centers

  • 1 -- At Least -- Offsite

  • OneDrive Cloud

  • Published Stuff on GitHub

docs.title: Monthly and Significant Milestone System Image Instructions
Whats Included:
docs.text: • Full Raspberry Pi Development System

docs.title: When to Back Up:
docs.text:
• At Least Monthly while actively working
  • After major changes or successful GitHub Pages deployments
  • Before system upgrades or Raspberry Pi changes
  • Periodically, as insurance against SD card failure

docs.title: Step-by-Step System Image
docs.text:
Close all files and apps

Use Raspberry Pi Imager to make a backup image on a separate Micro SD Card

Make a compressed image of the backup card that can be stored in multiple places.

Raspberry Pi SD Shrink + Image Checklist

Make sure gparted is installed:

sudo apt update

sudo apt install gparted

Run gparted to shrink the partition (is this necessary?)

sudo gparted

Right click on the lock icon to unlock the ext4 partition -- Probably sdb2

Shrink the partition as much as possible.

There is a step in the process to zero out free space but I think Raspberry Pi shrinker does that so skipping for now.

Make the image:

sudo dd if=/dev/sdb of=2025_05_27_zBITX-Wiki_MVP_2.img bs=4M status=progress

sudo dd if=/dev/sdb of=2025_05_31_zbitx-wiki.img bs=4M status=progress

yyyy_mm_dd_zbitx-wiki.img

\ sync

Shrink & make the image auto-expand (recommended) \ Install PiShrink:

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Drewsif/PiShrink/master/pishrink.sh

chmod +x pishrink.sh

sudo mv pishrink.sh /usr/local/bin

Run pishrink:

sudo pishrink.sh 2025_05_31_zbitx-wiki.img

yyyy_mm_dd_zbitx-wiki.img

Compress the image:

xz -9 2025_05_31_zbitx-wiki.img

yyyy_mm_dd_zbitx-wiki.img

  1. → You now have raspberrypi.img.xz

  2. Save the image in Large Files Repository and MyBook External

  3. Restore the image with Raspberry Pi Imager or flash:

xzcat raspberrypi.img.xz | sudo dd of=/dev/sdX bs=4M status=progress

docs.title: Reminders
docs.text:
reminders.md

Create (or Recreate) Virtual Environment:\ python3 -m env zbitx-wiki-env

Activate Virtual Environment:\ For mkdocs-starter: source env/bin/activate

Deactivate Virtual Environment:\ deactivate

You can save your Python environment in case you need to rebuild again:

pip freeze > requirements.txt

[DONE 5/31/25]{.underline}

Then in the future you can restore with:

pip install -r requirements.txt

Before Shutting Down, move out of project directoy:\ cd \~

Preferred Shutdown Method:\ sudo shutdown now

Linux_CL_Reminders

sudo apt-get update

sudo apt-get upgrade

sudo apt-get dist-upgrade

logout or exit

sudo reboot

sudo shutdown -h now

sudo raspi-config

This Wiki Site:

https://n5qc.github.io/zbitx-wiki/
